body:
hello @t4t5 thank you so much for getting back to us and my apologies for saying that. Open source is both a gift and a curse, that's why collaborators are here for.

I know that sometimes we need to focus on something else and it's always a good choice to invite collaborators.

Perhaps we could merge your repo with sweetalert2?

Cheers
Thanks @t4t5 i understood your point and @lancedouglas1 thanks for your swal-form link ...

@t4t5 - yes, the email did submit at first until I modified the code in an attempt to stop the send function if nothing was typed in the fields.

Surely there has to be a way to stop SweetAlert from submitting the form and verify there are actually valid values entered in the fields? I would really like to get form validation working on Swal. Otherwise I am looking at using Wordpress' Contact Form 7 with pop-up as a work around.
@t4t5 It's just a convention. Some of projects (eg. React, Redux) put source code (es6, es7) in `src`, compiled es5 in `lib`, umd and minified files in `dist`.
@chentsulin Oh I see. Seems like a good convention. Merging now.

@t4t5 why a `.npmignore` in the published module (1.1.1)?



`lib` in `.npmignore` will break this module. Must remove it.

If I can help, let me know.

@t4t5 I think that's a good solution. Currently isn't there only one sweet alert object, and it gets modified every time it pops up? Will having multiples around throw anything off? @t4t5 Maybe this: if you pass in a string to swal(), it's behavior is
unchanged. If you want swal() to function as a modal, you set a new
parameter, content, to the selector of the div you want to use in the swal
object? I think there could still be only one then.

wrote:

@t4t5 I think that having the markup and the parameters (via the data-\* attributes) of the modal in the html would be really cool.
Then to open an alert you would have to pass the alert id to the `swal()` function.

Example:





Would add a cancel button then show the modal by adding it the class "current-sweetalert-modal" (to avoid collision with others current classes that the user could have in it's `CSS`.

We could recommend/use a [client-side templating engine](http://garann.github.io/template-chooser/) to structure it all. I personally favour React.js because it supports type validation out of the box when you pass in properties to a component, but of course anything else could work. 

I think the only problem with this solution might be that this would require a significant rewrite. Specifically, `sweetalert-dev.js` has a `switch` statement with an object case that simply updates the default params, rather than let you define your own. Like @t4t5 mentions, there is only one SweetAlert box that keeps getting updated each time. We need a way to 'subclass' objects - to have a base `SweetAlert` object that simply checks the `type` argument supplied, and then calls the template involved. 

One way to do this - and the one I think would be most painless, given how extensive SweetAlert is - would be to have a function called `registerTemplate()`, which registers a template in a store accessible to `swal`. `swal` would then check the `type` argument on being invoked against an internal list -`success`,`input`,`error`,`warning` - and, if not found, default to passing all other arguments to the template and somehow render it. I think `_sweetAlertInitialize$getModal$getOverlay$getInput$setFocusStyle$openModal$resetInput$fixVerticalPosition` might be able to handle the rendering, although I'd have to take a closer look at it, I'm not sure.
@t4t5 - Can the second swal function confirm have a callback function? doesn't seem to work to me.

I am using it on Meteor using this great package https://github.com/kevohagan/meteor-sweetalert so after further debugging I think the problem is on the version the package is currently using, so I will look for a way to update the version of the package, thanks @xming13 !

Indeed @mwakerman . Actually, my purpose was to use sweet alert as a process notifier. In that case, we cannot assume the time that is needed. So, an event handler should be added.

I agree, that a close event would be better, as @mwakerman is right, that it will be on the event queue, since the function does use setTimeout. if its `swal('close')` or swal.cancel is up to @t4t5 to choose.

@t4t5 OK, actually the focus thing makes sense, since the modal elements are being hidden and not removed. Storing the state of document.activeElement and restoring it on close should be sufficient to stop that behaviour. The 2nd pull wasn't a duplicate, it had a 1 line fix for the tab problem (preventing default tab action when the modal is open), but I forgot to close the first PR so I  can see why it wasn't obvious.

@pomeh I don't know what @t4t5 's stance on this is, but personally I think the blocking parts of the vanilla alert are the worst parts about it, and one of the reasons that I would want to use something else. A modern piece of web software shouldn't be trying to lock a user.
The solution provided by @nixta seems to have done the trick, so I went ahead and merged that one. Thanks to everyone who contributed to this feature! :)

@connyay Yeah - I don't think I would have run jshint or JsFormat on someone else's code (certainly not in the same PR as something else I'm working on).  There's nothing wrong with a stylistic PR, but it comes across as petty/presumptive when you do it in the same commit as a material change.  Instead of being "hey, I made this pass jshint - what do you think?", it says "clearly a _professional_ would have used the same style as me, so I'm just going to presume that mine is better and change it without talking about it."  I understand that that wasn't your intention, but that's how it reads.

Congrats on your first PR!

To quote from #571

> ## @t4t5 commented on 26 Apr 2016
> 
> The project isn't dead. I just haven't had time to go through pull requests and issues lately.
> 
> sweetalert2 was forked before v1.0, so the structure of the project is quite different. This doesn't necessarily mean that it's not a good alternative. If there's a feature in there that you need, you should of course use it.
> 
> It kinda bugs me that it's called sweetalert2 though, since that makes it sound like it's a natural progression of this project, even though I'm planning a 2.0 release later this year...
> 
> Anyways, free software, do what you like. Just wanted to say sorry for being unresponsive, and that I'm planning on becoming more active soon.
> 
> If there are any good candidates to help me maintain the project, please let me know!
